an3.26:1.1.eng: “These three individuals are found in the world.

an3.26:1.3.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, puggalo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo.
an3.26:1.3.eng: There is an individual you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend.

an3.26:1.4.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, puggalo sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo.
an3.26:1.4.eng: There is an individual you should associate with, accompany, and attend.

an3.26:1.5.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, puggalo sakkatvā garuṃ katvā sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo.
an3.26:1.5.eng: There is an individual you should associate with, accompany, and attend with honor and respect.

an3.26:1.6.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo?
an3.26:1.6.eng: Who is the individual you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend?

an3.26:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo hīno hoti sīlena samādhinā paññāya.
an3.26:1.7.eng: It’s an individual who is inferior in terms of ethics, immersion, and wisdom.

an3.26:1.8.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, puggalo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo aññatra anuddayā aññatra anukampā.
an3.26:1.8.eng: You shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend such an individual, except out of kindness and sympathy.

an3.26:2.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo?
an3.26:2.1.eng: Who is the individual you should associate with, accompany, and attend?

an3.26:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo sadiso hoti sīlena samādhinā paññāya.
an3.26:2.2.eng: It’s an individual who is similar in terms of ethics, immersion, and wisdom.

an3.26:2.3.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, puggalo sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo.
an3.26:2.3.eng: You should associate with, accompany, and attend such an individual.

an3.26:2.5.pli: Sīlasāmaññagatānaṃ sataṃ sīlakathā ca no bhavissati, sā ca no pavattinī bhavissati, sā ca no phāsu bhavissati.
an3.26:2.5.eng: Thinking, ‘Since our ethical conduct is similar, we can discuss ethics, the conversation will flow, and we’ll both be at ease.

an3.26:2.6.pli: Samādhisāmaññagatānaṃ sataṃ samādhikathā ca no bhavissati, sā ca no pavattinī bhavissati, sā ca no phāsu bhavissati.
an3.26:2.6.eng: Since our immersion is similar, we can discuss immersion, the conversation will flow, and we’ll both be at ease.

an3.26:2.7.pli: Paññāsāmaññagatānaṃ sataṃ paññākathā ca no bhavissati, sā ca no pavattinī bhavissati, sā ca no phāsu bhavissatīti.
an3.26:2.7.eng: Since our wisdom is similar, we can discuss wisdom, the conversation will flow, and we’ll both be at ease.’

an3.26:2.8.pli: Tasmā evarūpo puggalo sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo.
an3.26:2.8.eng: That’s why you should associate with, accompany, and attend such an individual.

an3.26:3.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo sakkatvā garuṃ katvā sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo?
an3.26:3.1.eng: Who is the individual you should associate with, accompany, and attend with honor and respect?

an3.26:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo adhiko hoti sīlena samādhinā paññāya.
an3.26:3.2.eng: It’s an individual who is superior in terms of ethics, immersion, and wisdom.

an3.26:3.3.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, puggalo sakkatvā garuṃ katvā sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo.
an3.26:3.3.eng: You should associate with, accompany, and attend such an individual with honor and respect.

an3.26:3.5.pli: Iti aparipūraṃ vā sīlakkhandhaṃ paripūressāmi, paripūraṃ vā sīlakkhandhaṃ tattha tattha paññāya anuggahessāmi;
an3.26:3.5.eng: Thinking, ‘I’ll fulfill the entire spectrum of ethical conduct I haven’t yet fulfilled, or support with wisdom in every situation the ethical conduct I’ve already fulfilled.

an3.26:3.6.pli: aparipūraṃ vā samādhikkhandhaṃ paripūressāmi, paripūraṃ vā samādhikkhandhaṃ tattha tattha paññāya anuggahessāmi;
an3.26:3.6.eng: I’ll fulfill the entire spectrum of immersion I haven’t yet fulfilled, or support with wisdom in every situation the immersion I’ve already fulfilled.

an3.26:3.7.pli: aparipūraṃ vā paññākkhandhaṃ paripūressāmi, paripūraṃ vā paññākkhandhaṃ tattha tattha paññāya anuggahessāmīti.
an3.26:3.7.eng: I’ll fulfill the entire spectrum of wisdom I haven’t yet fulfilled, or support with wisdom in every situation the wisdom I’ve already fulfilled.’

an3.26:3.8.pli: Tasmā evarūpo puggalo sakkatvā garuṃ katvā sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo.
an3.26:3.8.eng: That’s why you should associate with, accompany, and attend this individual with honor and respect.

an3.26:3.9.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasminti.
an3.26:3.9.eng: These are the three individuals found in the world.

an3.26:4.1.eng: A man who associates with an inferior goes downhill,

an3.26:4.2.eng: but associating with an equal, you’ll never decline;

an3.26:4.3.eng: following the best, you’ll quickly rise up,

an3.26:4.4.eng: so you should keep company <j>with people better than you.”

an3.27:1.1.eng: “These three individuals are found in the world.

an3.27:1.3.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, puggalo jigucchitabbo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo.
an3.27:1.3.eng: There is an individual you should be disgusted by, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.

an3.27:1.4.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, puggalo ajjhupekkhitabbo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo.
an3.27:1.4.eng: There is an individual you should regard with equanimity, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.

an3.27:1.5.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, puggalo sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo.
an3.27:1.5.eng: There is an individual you should associate with, accompany, and attend.

an3.27:1.6.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo jigucchitabbo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo?
an3.27:1.6.eng: Who is the individual you should be disgusted by, and not associate with, accompany, or attend?

an3.27:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo dussīlo hoti pāpadhammo asuci saṅkassarasamācāro paṭicchannakammanto, assamaṇo samaṇapaṭiñño, abrahmacārī brahmacāripaṭiñño, antopūti avassuto kasambujāto.
an3.27:1.7.eng: It’s an individual who is unethical, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, festering, and depraved.

an3.27:1.8.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, puggalo jigucchitabbo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo.
an3.27:1.8.eng: You should be disgusted by such an individual, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.

an3.27:1.10.pli: Kiñcāpi, bhikkhave, evarūpassa puggalassa na diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati, atha kho naṃ pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati:
an3.27:1.10.eng: Even if you don’t follow the example of such an individual, you still get a bad reputation:

an3.27:1.11.eng: ‘That individual has bad friends, companions, and associates.’

an3.27:1.12.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ahi gūthagato kiñcāpi na daṃsati, atha kho naṃ makkheti;
an3.27:1.12.eng: They’re like a snake that’s been living in a pile of dung. Even if it doesn’t bite, it’ll still rub off on you.

an3.27:1.13.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, kiñcāpi evarūpassa puggalassa na diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati, atha kho naṃ pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchati:
an3.27:1.13.eng: In the same way, even if you don’t follow the example of such an individual, you still get a bad reputation:

an3.27:1.14.eng: ‘That individual has bad friends, companions, and associates.’

an3.27:1.15.pli: Tasmā evarūpo puggalo jigucchitabbo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo.
an3.27:1.15.eng: That’s why you should be disgusted by such an individual, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.

an3.27:2.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo ajjhupekkhitabbo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo?
an3.27:2.1.eng: Who is the individual you should regard with equanimity, and not associate with, accompany, or attend?

an3.27:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo kodhano hoti upāyāsabahulo,
an3.27:2.2.eng: It’s an individual who is irritable and bad-tempered.

an3.27:2.3.pli: appampi vutto samāno abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patitthīyati, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an3.27:2.3.eng: Even when lightly criticized they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and they display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an3.27:2.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, duṭṭhāruko kaṭṭhena vā kaṭhalāya vā ghaṭṭito bhiyyoso mattāya āsavaṃ deti;
an3.27:2.4.eng: They’re like a festering sore, which, when you hit it with a stick or a stone, discharges even more.

an3.27:2.5.eng: In the same way, someone is irritable and bad-tempered.

an3.27:2.6.pli: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, tindukālātaṃ kaṭṭhena vā kaṭhalāya vā ghaṭṭitaṃ bhiyyoso mattāya cicciṭāyati ciṭiciṭāyati;
an3.27:2.6.eng: They’re like a firebrand of pale-moon ebony, which, when you hit it with a stick or a stone, sizzles and crackles even more.

an3.27:2.7.eng: In the same way, someone is irritable and bad-tempered.

an3.27:2.8.pli: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gūthakūpo kaṭṭhena vā kaṭhalāya vā ghaṭṭito bhiyyoso mattāya duggandho hoti;
an3.27:2.8.eng: They’re like a sewer, which, when you stir it with a stick or a stone, stinks even more.

an3.27:2.9.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo kodhano hoti upāyāsabahulo,
an3.27:2.9.eng: In the same way, an individual is irritable and bad-tempered.

an3.27:2.10.pli: appampi vutto samāno abhisajjati kuppati byāpajjati patitthīyati, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātukaroti.
an3.27:2.10.eng: Even when lightly criticized they lose their temper, becoming annoyed, hostile, and hard-hearted, and they display annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

an3.27:2.11.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, puggalo ajjhupekkhitabbo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo.
an3.27:2.11.eng: You should regard such an individual with equanimity, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.

an3.27:2.13.pli: Akkoseyyapi maṃ paribhāseyyapi maṃ anatthampi maṃ kareyyāti.
an3.27:2.13.eng: Thinking, ‘They might abuse or insult me, or do me harm.’

an3.27:2.14.pli: Tasmā evarūpo puggalo ajjhupekkhitabbo na sevitabbo na bhajitabbo na payirupāsitabbo.
an3.27:2.14.eng: That’s why you should regard such an individual with equanimity, and you shouldn’t associate with, accompany, or attend them.

an3.27:3.1.pli: Katamo ca, bhikkhave, puggalo sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo?
an3.27:3.1.eng: Who is the individual you should associate with, accompany, and attend?

an3.27:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo sīlavā hoti kalyāṇadhammo.
an3.27:3.2.eng: It’s an individual who is ethical, of good character.

an3.27:3.3.pli: Evarūpo, bhikkhave, puggalo sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo.
an3.27:3.3.eng: You should associate with, accompany, and attend such an individual.

an3.27:3.5.pli: Kiñcāpi, bhikkhave, evarūpassa puggalassa na diṭṭhānugatiṃ āpajjati, atha kho naṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggacchati:
an3.27:3.5.eng: Even if you don’t follow the example of such an individual, you still get a good reputation:

an3.27:3.6.eng: ‘That individual has good friends, companions, and associates.’

an3.27:3.7.pli: Tasmā evarūpo puggalo sevitabbo bhajitabbo payirupāsitabbo.
an3.27:3.7.eng: That’s why you should associate with, accompany, and attend such an individual.

an3.27:3.8.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasminti.
an3.27:3.8.eng: These are the three individuals found in the world.

an3.27:4.1.eng: A man who associates with an inferior goes downhill,

an3.27:4.2.eng: but associating with an equal, you’ll never decline;

an3.27:4.3.eng: following the best, you’ll quickly rise up,

an3.27:4.4.eng: so you should keep company <j>with people better than you.”

an3.28:1.1.eng: “These three individuals are found in the world.

an3.28:1.3.eng: One with speech like dung, one with speech like flowers, and one with speech like honey.

an3.28:1.4.eng: And who has speech like dung?

an3.28:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo sabhaggato vā parisaggato vā ñātimajjhagato vā pūgamajjhagato vā rājakulamajjhagato vā abhinīto sakkhipuṭṭho: ‘ehambho purisa, yaṃ jānāsi taṃ vadehī’ti. So ajānaṃ vā āha: ‘jānāmī’ti, jānaṃ vā āha: ‘na jānāmī’ti, apassaṃ vā āha: ‘passāmī’ti, passaṃ vā āha: ‘na passāmī’ti; iti attahetu vā parahetu vā āmisakiñcikkhahetu vā sampajānamusā bhāsitā hoti.
an3.28:1.5.eng: It’s an individual who is summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, mister, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ So they deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.

an3.28:1.6.eng: This is called an individual with speech like dung.

an3.28:2.1.eng: And who has speech like flowers?

an3.28:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo sabhaggato vā parisaggato vā ñātimajjhagato vā pūgamajjhagato vā rājakulamajjhagato vā abhinīto sakkhipuṭṭho: ‘ehambho purisa, yaṃ pajānāsi taṃ vadehī’ti, so ajānaṃ vā āha: ‘na jānāmī’ti, jānaṃ vā āha: ‘jānāmī’ti, apassaṃ vā āha: ‘na passāmī’ti, passaṃ vā āha: ‘passāmī’ti; iti attahetu vā parahetu vā āmisakiñcikkhahetu vā na sampajānamusā bhāsitā hoti.
an3.28:2.2.eng: It’s an individual who is summoned to a council, an assembly, a family meeting, a guild, or to the royal court, and asked to bear witness: ‘Please, mister, say what you know.’ Not knowing, they say ‘I don’t know.’ Knowing, they say ‘I know.’ Not seeing, they say ‘I don’t see.’ And seeing, they say ‘I see.’ So they don’t deliberately lie for the sake of themselves or another, or for some trivial worldly reason.

an3.28:2.3.eng: This is called an individual with speech like flowers.

an3.28:3.1.eng: And who has speech like honey?

an3.28:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti;
an3.28:3.2.eng: It’s an individual who gives up harsh speech.

an3.28:3.3.pli: yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
an3.28:3.3.eng: They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

an3.28:3.4.eng: This is called an individual with speech like honey.

an3.28:3.5.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an3.28:3.5.eng: These are the three individuals found in the world.”

an3.29:1.1.eng: “These three individuals are found in the world.

an3.29:1.3.eng: The blind, the one-eyed, and the two-eyed.

an3.29:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa puggalassa tathārūpaṃ cakkhu na hoti yathārūpena cakkhunā anadhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ adhigaccheyya adhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ phātiṃ kareyya;
an3.29:1.5.eng: It’s someone who doesn’t have the kind of vision that’s needed to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth they’ve already acquired.

an3.29:1.6.pli: tathārūpampissa cakkhu na hoti yathārūpena cakkhunā kusalākusale dhamme jāneyya, sāvajjānavajje dhamme jāneyya, hīnappaṇīte dhamme jāneyya, kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāge dhamme jāneyya.
an3.29:1.6.eng: Nor do they have the kind of vision that’s needed to know the difference between qualities that are skillful and unskillful, blameworthy and blameless, inferior and superior, and those on the side of dark and bright.

an3.29:1.7.eng: This is called a blind individual.

an3.29:2.1.eng: Who is the individual with one eye?

an3.29:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa puggalassa tathārūpaṃ cakkhu hoti yathārūpena cakkhunā anadhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ adhigaccheyya adhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ phātiṃ kareyya;
an3.29:2.2.eng: It’s someone who has the kind of vision that’s needed to acquire more wealth and to increase the wealth they’ve already acquired.

an3.29:2.3.pli: tathārūpaṃ panassa cakkhu na hoti yathārūpena cakkhunā kusalākusale dhamme jāneyya, sāvajjānavajje dhamme jāneyya, hīnappaṇīte dhamme jāneyya, kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāge dhamme jāneyya.
an3.29:2.3.eng: But they don’t have the kind of vision that’s needed to know the difference between qualities that are skillful and unskillful, blameworthy and blameless, inferior and superior, and those on the side of dark and bright.

an3.29:2.4.eng: This is called a one-eyed individual.

an3.29:3.1.eng: Who is the individual with two eyes?

an3.29:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccassa puggalassa tathārūpaṃ cakkhu hoti yathārūpena cakkhunā anadhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ adhigaccheyya, adhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ phātiṃ kareyya;
an3.29:3.2.eng: It’s someone who has the kind of vision that’s needed to acquire more wealth and to increase the wealth they’ve already acquired.

an3.29:3.3.pli: tathārūpampissa cakkhu hoti yathārūpena cakkhunā kusalākusale dhamme jāneyya;
an3.29:3.3.eng: And they have the kind of vision that’s needed to know the difference between skillful and unskillful, blameworthy and blameless, inferior and superior, or qualities on the side of dark and bright.

an3.29:3.4.pli: sāvajjānavajje dhamme jāneyya, hīnappaṇīte dhamme jāneyya, kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāge dhamme jāneyya.

an3.29:3.5.eng: This is called a two-eyed individual.

an3.29:3.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasminti.
an3.29:3.6.eng: These are the three individuals found in the world.

an3.29:4.3.eng: They hold a losing hand on both counts,

an3.29:4.4.eng: those who are blind, with ruined eyes.

an3.29:6.3.eng: the young man’s skilled at piling up money,

an3.29:6.5.eng: From here they go to hell—

an3.29:7.1.eng: And now the two-eyed is explained,

an3.29:7.4.eng: money acquired by their own hard work.

an3.29:8.1.eng: They give with best of intentions,

an3.29:8.3.eng: They go to a good place,

an3.29:9.3.eng: But you should keep the two-eyed close,

an3.3:1.1.eng: “There are these three characteristics, signs, and manifestations of a fool.

an3.3:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bālo duccintitacintī ca hoti dubbhāsitabhāsī ca dukkaṭakammakārī ca.
an3.3:1.3.eng: A fool thinks poorly, speaks poorly, and acts poorly.

an3.3:1.4.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, bālo duccintitacintī ca abhavissa dubbhāsitabhāsī ca dukkaṭakammakārī ca, kena naṃ paṇḍitā jāneyyuṃ:
an3.3:1.4.eng: If a fool didn’t think poorly, speak poorly, and act poorly, then how would the astute know of them:

an3.3:1.5.eng: ‘This worthy one is a fool, an untrue person’?

an3.3:1.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, bālo duccintitacintī ca hoti dubbhāsitabhāsī ca dukkaṭakammakārī ca tasmā naṃ paṇḍitā jānanti:
an3.3:1.6.eng: But since a fool does think poorly, speak poorly, and act poorly, then the astute do know of them:

an3.3:1.7.eng: ‘This worthy one is a fool, an untrue person’.

an3.3:1.8.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi bālassa bālalakkhaṇāni bālanimittāni bālāpadānāni.
an3.3:1.8.eng: These are the three characteristics, signs, and manifestations of a fool.

an3.3:2.1.pli: Tīṇimāni, bhikkhave, paṇḍitassa paṇḍitalakkhaṇāni paṇḍitanimittāni paṇḍitāpadānāni.
an3.3:2.1.eng: There are these three characteristics, signs, and manifestations of an astute person.

an3.3:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, paṇḍito sucintitacintī ca hoti subhāsitabhāsī ca sukatakammakārī ca.
an3.3:2.3.eng: An astute person thinks well, speaks well, and acts well.

an3.3:2.4.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, paṇḍito sucintitacintī ca abhavissa subhāsitabhāsī ca sukatakammakārī ca, kena naṃ paṇḍitā jāneyyuṃ:
an3.3:2.4.eng: If an astute person didn’t think well, speak well, and act well, then how would the astute know of them:

an3.3:2.5.eng: ‘This worthy one is astute, a true person’?

an3.3:2.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, paṇḍito sucintitacintī ca hoti subhāsitabhāsī ca sukatakammakārī ca tasmā naṃ paṇḍitā jānanti:
an3.3:2.6.eng: But since an astute person does think well, speak well, and act well, then the astute do know of them:

an3.3:2.7.eng: ‘This worthy one is astute, a true person’.

an3.3:2.8.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi paṇḍitassa paṇḍitalakkhaṇāni paṇḍitanimittāni paṇḍitāpadānāni.
an3.3:2.8.eng: These are the three characteristics, signs, and manifestations of an astute person.

an3.30:1.1.eng: “These three individuals are found in the world.

an3.30:1.3.pli: Avakujjapañño puggalo, ucchaṅgapañño puggalo, puthupañño puggalo.
an3.30:1.3.eng: One with upside-down wisdom, one with wisdom on their lap, and one with widespread wisdom.

an3.30:1.4.eng: And who is the individual with upside-down wisdom?

an3.30:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ārāmaṃ gantā hoti abhikkhaṇaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santike dhammassavanāya.
an3.30:1.5.eng: It’s an individual who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.

an3.30:1.6.pli: Tassa bhikkhū dhammaṃ desenti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsenti.
an3.30:1.6.eng: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an3.30:1.7.pli: So tasmiṃ āsane nisinno tassā kathāya neva ādiṃ manasi karoti, na majjhaṃ manasi karoti, na pariyosānaṃ manasi karoti;
an3.30:1.7.eng: But even while sitting there, that person doesn’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.

an3.30:1.8.pli: vuṭṭhitopi tamhā āsanā tassā kathāya neva ādiṃ manasi karoti, na majjhaṃ manasi karoti, na pariyosānaṃ manasi karoti.
an3.30:1.8.eng: And when they get up from their seat, they don’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.

an3.30:1.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kumbho nikujjo tatra udakaṃ āsittaṃ vivaṭṭati, no saṇṭhāti;
an3.30:1.9.eng: It’s like when a pot full of water is tipped over, so the water drains out and doesn’t stay.

an3.30:1.10.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo ārāmaṃ gantā hoti abhikkhaṇaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santike dhammassavanāya.
an3.30:1.10.eng: In the same way, an individual often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.

an3.30:1.11.pli: Tassa bhikkhū dhammaṃ desenti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsenti.
an3.30:1.11.eng: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an3.30:1.12.pli: So tasmiṃ āsane nisinno tassā kathāya neva ādiṃ manasi karoti, na majjhaṃ manasi karoti, na pariyosānaṃ manasi karoti;
an3.30:1.12.eng: But even while sitting there, that person doesn’t apply the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, or end.

an3.30:1.13.pli: vuṭṭhitopi tamhā āsanā tassā kathāya neva ādiṃ manasi karoti, na majjhaṃ manasi karoti, na pariyosānaṃ manasi karoti.
an3.30:1.13.eng: And when they get up from their seat, they don’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.

an3.30:1.14.eng: This is called an individual with upside-down wisdom.

an3.30:2.1.eng: And who is the individual with wisdom on their lap?

an3.30:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ārāmaṃ gantā hoti abhikkhaṇaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santike dhammassavanāya.
an3.30:2.2.eng: It’s an individual who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.

an3.30:2.3.pli: Tassa bhikkhū dhammaṃ desenti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsenti.
an3.30:2.3.eng: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an3.30:2.4.pli: So tasmiṃ āsane nisinno tassā kathāya ādimpi manasi karoti, majjhampi manasi karoti, pariyosānampi manasi karoti;
an3.30:2.4.eng: While sitting there, that person applies the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.

an3.30:2.5.pli: vuṭṭhito ca kho tamhā āsanā tassā kathāya neva ādiṃ manasi karoti, na majjhaṃ manasi karoti, na pariyosānaṃ manasi karoti.
an3.30:2.5.eng: But when they get up from their seat, they don’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.

an3.30:2.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, purisassa ucchaṅge nānākhajjakāni ākiṇṇāni—
an3.30:2.6.eng: It’s like a person who has different kinds of food crammed on their lap—

an3.30:2.7.eng: such as sesame, rice, sweets, or jujube—

an3.30:2.8.pli: So tamhā āsanā vuṭṭhahanto satisammosā pakireyya.
an3.30:2.8.eng: so that if they get up from the seat without mindfulness, everything gets scattered.

an3.30:2.9.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo ārāmaṃ gantā hoti abhikkhaṇaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santike dhammassavanāya.
an3.30:2.9.eng: In the same way, an individual often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.

an3.30:2.10.pli: Tassa bhikkhū dhammaṃ desenti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsenti.
an3.30:2.10.eng: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an3.30:2.11.pli: So tasmiṃ āsane nisinno tassā kathāya ādimpi manasi karoti, majjhampi manasi karoti, pariyosānampi manasi karoti;
an3.30:2.11.eng: While sitting there, that person applies the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.

an3.30:2.12.pli: vuṭṭhito ca kho tamhā āsanā tassā kathāya neva ādiṃ manasi karoti, na majjhaṃ manasi karoti, na pariyosānaṃ manasi karoti.
an3.30:2.12.eng: But when they get up from their seat, they don’t apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.

an3.30:2.13.eng: This is called an individual with wisdom on their lap.

an3.30:3.1.eng: And who is the individual with widespread wisdom?

an3.30:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo ārāmaṃ gantā hoti abhikkhaṇaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santike dhammassavanāya.
an3.30:3.2.eng: It’s an individual who often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.

an3.30:3.3.pli: Tassa bhikkhū dhammaṃ desenti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsenti.
an3.30:3.3.eng: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an3.30:3.4.pli: So tasmiṃ āsane nisinno tassā kathāya ādimpi manasi karoti, majjhampi manasi karoti, pariyosānampi manasi karoti;
an3.30:3.4.eng: While sitting there, they apply the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.

an3.30:3.5.pli: vuṭṭhitopi tamhā āsanā tassā kathāya ādimpi manasi karoti, majjhampi manasi karoti, pariyosānampi manasi karoti.
an3.30:3.5.eng: And when they get up from their seat, they continue to apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.

an3.30:3.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kumbho ukkujjo tatra udakaṃ āsittaṃ saṇṭhāti no vivaṭṭati;
an3.30:3.6.eng: It’s like when a pot full of water is set straight, so the water stays and doesn’t drain out.

an3.30:3.7.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo ārāmaṃ gantā hoti abhikkhaṇaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ santike dhammassavanāya.
an3.30:3.7.eng: In the same way, an individual often goes to the monastery to hear the teaching in the presence of the mendicants.

an3.30:3.8.pli: Tassa bhikkhū dhammaṃ desenti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsenti.
an3.30:3.8.eng: The mendicants teach them Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And they reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

an3.30:3.9.pli: So tasmiṃ āsane nisinno tassā kathāya ādimpi manasi karoti, majjhampi manasi karoti, pariyosānampi manasi karoti;
an3.30:3.9.eng: While sitting there, they apply the mind to the discussion in the beginning, middle, and end.

an3.30:3.10.pli: vuṭṭhitopi tamhā āsanā tassā kathāya ādimpi manasi karoti, majjhampi manasi karoti, pariyosānampi manasi karoti.
an3.30:3.10.eng: And when they get up from their seat, they continue to apply the mind to the beginning, middle, or end of the discussion.

an3.30:3.11.eng: This is called an individual with widespread wisdom.

an3.30:3.12.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasminti.
an3.30:3.12.eng: These are the three individuals found in the world.

an3.30:6.1.eng: the individual with wisdom on their lap

an3.30:7.1.eng: such a person can only learn

an3.30:7.4.eng: but they’ve only grasped the phrasing,

an3.30:7.5.eng: for when they get up their understanding fails,

an3.30:7.6.eng: and what they’ve learned is lost.

an3.30:9.4.eng: and when they’ve grasped the phrasing,

an3.30:10.1.eng: they remember it with the best of intentions.

an3.30:10.4.eng: would make an end of suffering.”
